node.title: Are our CBDs dying, or is the role they play just evolving?
node.alt: Shopfronts in poor condition with graffiti
node.description: COVID has nearly killed the city centre. Now experts are pondering what the future of the CBD will be in post-pandemic Australia.
node.content:
["Walking down Flinders Street in the tropical city of Townsville, it is\u00a0hard to believe you are in the heart of a thriving regional capital in the midst of a population boom.\u00a0", "There are vacant storefronts, cafes with no customers \u2014 and foot traffic is scarce.", "Academics say this city isn't an outlier, but the\u00a0norm\u00a0as the way Australians are using CBDs is changing.", "
CBD not attracting\u00a0big-name retail\u00a0
", "Real estate agency\u00a0Knight Frank's Craig Stack said Townsville's commercial vacancy rate was relatively high,\u00a0sitting at about 20 per cent.", "He said historically, in regional Queensland, big-name retailers were located further out of the CBD.", "", "
Knight Frank's Craig Stack says more people need to live in the CBD for it to thrive.(ABC North Queensland: Zilla Gordon)
", "\"I'd go one step further and say we're now\u00a0seeing that [trend] in the metro\u00a0capital cities CBDs where those high streets aren't attracting the same type of retailers,\" he said.", "But Mr Stack said if Townsville wanted to revitalise its town centre, more people had to live in the CBD.", "\"For people living in new developments outside of the city centre, their need to go to the [CBD] other than [for] work \u2026 is going to be minimal,\" he said.", "\"It's common throughout regional Australia to see that drift away from city centres occurring, and the [cities] that are reversing that drift are the ones that are focussed on peopling living in [the CBD].\"", "
Is the CBD dead?
", "Associate professor for urban planning at the University of Melbourne, Crystal Legacy, said the question of whether the CBD was dying was on a lot of planners' minds.\u00a0", "", "
University of Melbourne's Crystal Legacy says initiatives like free parking is not a long-term solution.\u00a0 \u00a0 \u00a0(ABC North Queensland: Zilla Gordon)
", "Dr Legacy said future planning policy needed to reflect people's changing living and travel patterns, with more people shopping at their local main street rather than heading into the city centre.", "And while some cities, like Townsville in north Queensland, have previously offered free parking to draw people into town, Dr\u00a0Legacy said it wasn't a long-term solution.", "\"Most people are travelling into the city by themselves,\" she said.", "\"We should make sure we've got good quality public transport, bike lanes and pedestrian footpaths, so people feel comfortable walking in cities.\"", "
Different role for CBD in the future
", "And as to the future of city centres in Australia, Dr\u00a0Legacy said it was very much a live question.", "", "
Dr Legacy says the CBD can become a cultural hub\u00a0in the future.(ABC North Queensland: Zilla Gordon)
", "Dr Legacy said billions of dollars were currently being invested in infrastructure in Melbourne. But, in future,\u00a0city buildings might be used for social opportunities like co-working spaces\u00a0or cultural centres.", "\"I don't think we're going to see a situation where we're decommissioning these assets,\" she said.", "\"CBDs could play an increased role in terms of cultural and social capital and bringing people together for festivals and exhibitions, rather than just commerce and work, more generally. \"", "
Balancing act between suburbs and city
", "In Townsville, the CBD contributes more than $1 billion annually to the region's economy, but after two years of navigating COVID-19, the council is trying to get people back into town.", "Townsville councillor Ann-Maree Greaney said it was a balancing act between encouraging\u00a0locals to support their neighbourhood coffee shops as well as businesses operating in the town centre.", "", "
Townsville councillor Ann-Maree Greaney says it is a balancing act between supporting\u00a0suburbs and the city.\u00a0(ABC North Queensland: Zilla Gordon)
", "With shops sitting empty, Cr Greaney said the council was offering incentives to businesses to keep their shop fronts in good nick.", "The council is currently offering grant funding for 50 per cent of eligible costs to modernise buildings of up to $30,000 per project.", "Cr Greaney said a council-run market on Sundays had been successful in drawing weekend\u00a0crowds."]
